segments.text: These whole discussions were very impressive that much more needed to be done about radioactivity in the ocean, that the waste disposal problem ended up by being swept under the rug a good deal.
The really most apparent thing was that there was a tremendous amount of activity

huge financing, many corporations, national policy to produce radioactivity, and there were only very slight, small, low priority, feeble efforts and considerations of what one should do to try and take care of all of it after it had been produced, in case the nuclear program was successful in phase one.
Let's shut it off.
This earlier consideration of the radioactive problem is one that, like many others, I copped out on and had very little to do with it for quite a long time.
Some of the problems involved were so technically difficult that many oceanographers
felt the Atomic Energy Commission should not undertake some of the more complicated ways of looking at their problems, technical ways.
This, I think, didn't get done, and it is one of the things that
I believe our oceanographic community was not fair to PLACES like the Atomic Energy Commission, because really they wanted to move.
In some cases, they wanted to move ahead with, let's say, some of the optimist oceanographers, and some of the pessimist oceanographers sort of dampened their spirits.
I think that's enough on what activity I had with that NASCO committee.
It had a great influence on me because it did have to do with the future of the game and it showed that looking ahead
five or ten years, if you did your homework, was apt to be successful.
They asked for a third of a billion dollars in ten years, and they probably got twice that much.
It wasn't all spent the way they had recommended, which was probably a good thing, but it did show there was great action.
To my way of thinking, there has been no effort by oceanographers since that time that comes within a factor of
three of being as aggressive, as forward-looking, as constructive, and so forth.
I believe this is one of the reasons why we have been tending to do a little bit more floundering.
And it is basically that the oceanographers have not been doing their homework as well as Washington, and we have no complaint to make.
I would like to have one flashback here about the Ocean Resources Institute.
in Woods Hole, which was largely the brainchild of a naval architect, ocean engineer by the name of Francis Minot and Columbus Islin.
This started off as the Marine Fisheries and Engineering Organization, and that name was so cumbersome that
we changed.
I became one of the trustees of a fledgling organization that its office and laboratory was one small second floor office, seldom could afford a secretary.
And it lived off a few grants from the Crane Foundation and from
Columbus Island's uncle, and altogether too much from Columbus Island's personal pocketbook.
But it was a very real attempt, starting about 1951, to get the oceanographic and engineering aspects of the oceanography proceeding.
Columbus felt very strongly, and I certainly agreed with him, that a community such as Woods Hole should encompass more than just scientific oceanography.
One of his criteria for having a separate...
He had several criteria for having a separate organization, which I think were fairly sound.
One is he felt the...

If a director of an institution didn't have his hand in too many pies, well, then he could appear a little more realistic and have a few more hours a day to spend on the one that was the highest priority.
He also felt, which was either right or wrong, that academic people in academia that were free in a research place where they're completely free to choose their subject
should be willing to operate at lower salaries than people who were working on applied problems and were somewhat more under the thumb of somebody else.
And he felt the salary scale in a small, he had tried to have a dual salary scale in one institution where you were headed for trouble.
And if you were with separate organizations, you could have somewhat separate salary scales.
And any worker was free to work in either place.
He could get a job.
This was typical of the kind of administrative policies that Islin used.
Not everyone would agree that scientists should be paid less than engineers, but it may be if engineers had been paid more than scientists.
In oceanography, we would have had ocean engineering operating long before this.
Here again in the Ocean Resources Institute, which went under partly by bankruptcy and partly that the director, about 10 years later, died in an automobile accident, it never seemed to catch on.
The people couldn't understand it was such a good idea why the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution didn't do it
In a way, Revelle laid here because he set up a comparable kind of organization in Scripps and made it part of, made it a segment of Scripps.
It is now their marine resources institute.

Here at Woods Hole, the institution sort of died out and started up again in a somewhat different vein when Woods Hole started having departments, and one of them was a department of ocean engineering.
This, however, was significantly different because it was

I think conceived too much on the basis of being a facility to produce instruments for scientists and not enough of such things of worrying about safety at sea, the economics and engineering of getting industry to pick up oceanographic ideas a little quicker and trying to put them to use.
So as these things got talked about more in the oceanographic community, they began to get incorporated a little bit more.
The Marine Technology Society, for example, is an illustration of this.
But a good many years later,
when Islin was very sick and in the hospital a short time before he died.

He was in the Boston Hospital at one night when the AAAS was holding a meeting, and this meeting had been very much, or this, one or two sessions had been devoted to more of the industrial application of science.
And I remember going over and talking to Columbus
and saying, well, about 15 years later, where the AAAS finally got around to start talking about the same kinds of things he'd been talking about.
And I can remember that he, although he was pretty low on energy, he kind of grinned and said, well, aren't we lucky it's only been 15 years?
Shut it off.

To come back to the question of designing ships for the job, we did a little bit of work back in the late 50s in getting some informal proposals off the National Science Foundation for something like the Atlantis II.
and new ships for Scripps.
I know there are oftentimes problems in procurement which don't
show on the surface.
One of these was exemplified by Bill Benson, who was then in geology at National Science Foundation.
And he and I had spent a lot of time on this kind of thing, talking also with other oceanographers of essentially people contemporary with Bill and myself.
So he took the bull by the horns and got Ravel and Islin and had lunch with him.
I believe Art Maxwell was at that one.
Benson sort of made the suggestion that if the National Science Foundation could get some money for some ships, what kind of ships would they like and this sort of thing.
Here were these two directors of oceanographic institutions, and both of them said, we don't need any new ships.
We've got all the ships we need and certainly all we can afford, and they're good enough for us, and that sort of that.
We all had to go back to the drawing boards on that one for a while, but we did our homework on that one, a little bit of homework.
After Dr. Fye took over here at Woods Hole, he organized a ship committee to look into the design of a new ship
This took a good deal of time, and Francis Minot was the first chairman, and Dick Edwards the second chairman of it after Frank died.
But we worked very hard on the design of Atlantis II.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation got the design contract.
And one little instance here, which I think is important,
After about the fourth round of design, when it already looked like we'd been spending too much time on design, there was much talk about finishing that design and saying put it in production.

I had people go around the table and make their comments, and I felt a little embarrassed doing this, but I brought up the point that it took six weeks to do, a month to six weeks to do a redesign, and it cost about $25,000.
We'd already done this three times, and each time there was a vast improvement.
I thought if we went around, if we could face it one more time, we'd have a lot better ship.
And I was simply delighted that people went along with this.
The ship got to be big enough and solid enough to where it became really a kind of a true competitor, much more a true competitor with the chain.
And this ship probably had one of the best layouts
of any ship.
It's a very pleasant ship to work on from the standpoint of the way it is laid out.
This was an improvement on the designs of the Agors in which a large number of
working oceanographers decided that if they made off-center deckhouses and lopsided afterdecks, that then they could handle their equipment much better and have a much better physical layout.
Perhaps the biggest experiment in Atlantis II was to have a library in it.

The decision was to have a space which was at least as large as the captain's cabin and fixed up at least as well as the captain's cabin and establish a good library and a pleasant place to be with a library that was divided between
general fiction and travel and technology.
This has turned out to be a very successful thing.
We've incorporated it in our other ships.
It gives many more references available on the spot
provides much more education.
The level of reading material in the ship has improved many fold over what it had been in the past.
And one of the nicest things about it that has pleased me is when you're on an expedition in which there are people from other countries there,
It turns out that many of these people come from countries where the library isn't as good as we have on the Atlantis.
And it's indeed a pleasure to see people be able to tour over things, look up things on time.
It has greatly improved almost the semi-formal teaching of classes and courses, or at least of issues aboard the ship.
That may not seem like a very large step in seagoing, because some of the larger European ships have had this kind of thing for a long time.
American ships had not.
To continue a bit on ship building, ship designing, I continued to work with some of the other laboratories that were involved with ship
design where they were interested in having cooperation.
Still later when Woods Hole decided they needed a Crawford replacement, Dr. Fye asked me if I would be chairman of that ship committee and I was.
The other principal worker was John Leiby who was
largely responsible for so many fine things about the ship.
But I think on that ship committee, what we did is we had many very realistic discussions as to what did people want

what did the scientists want, and we tried to parcel out the kinds of things that different ships were best for, and this ship ended up to be primarily a ship for the physical oceanographic department, or I should say rather it was a ship that was specifically designed to do the kind of work they wanted to do as well as possible and work for
Some of the other departments took more of a back seat.
As a result, even though the ship was only 170 feet long, it was the fastest ship we have, and it's turned out to be a very good ship and a very happy ship.
People like to work on it.
One of the reasons, an example of one of the reasons why people should do their homework
And it pays to be positive about it.
Although Dr. Fye worked very hard, he was unable to get private funds for the ship, but we did get NSF to build it.
They made us come down on the specs some, and we had to take it as a bare boat, hardly with enough equipment to come away from the manufacturer.
But sort of just as we were going to order it, they said, incidentally, would you like to order two more?
So as a result, there are now three of those ships or slight variations of them in the game.
And I think the lesson here is to assume, if you're working in the right direction, to assume that there's a high probability you may have
have or find friends that will carry the game along even though it looks hopeless to you at the time.
In the last few years I've

been interested in, gotten interested in, was always in quite a variety of things, but I've gotten somewhat more extracurricular and somewhat longer range in the timescales of what I have been working on.
This may be an indication of old age.
I understand it's a general trend.
But also, our institution

started getting a lot of titles and the one of senior scientists they indicate it's a title in which people should be free to worry about longer term things and it's becoming very clear in our highly organized society
And the fact that young people have to publish or perish, and if they don't publish, they get booted out almost before you can find who they're capable of really good work or not.
But there are certain kinds of problems that...
are going to require more time.
And it seemed to me that if the institution set up the category of senior scientists, so this was one of the options open for them, that I would push that option a little harder than perhaps I might.
Recently, I've gotten very much interested in the particular aspect of how one does better sub-bottom profiling.
Now, what I have to say next may indicate that it may turn out to be wrong and a poor step.
But it is a general direction that we need higher resolution.
I think higher resolution is the name of the game in a great many things.
It's true of the BT.
It's true of the slowly corrected instruments.
It's true of the history of our science.
I think it is also true that astronomers as a whole use their physics more to help them understand the limits of measurement and then they try and achieve those.
In oceanography we tend to get somewhat more sloppy and concern ourselves with how poor measurements can we get by with.

High resolution sonar at high frequencies, whether used to locate mines or fish or what the doctor uses to determine what the sex of an unborn child is, has progressed much further than high resolution equipment in low frequency games that we use on ships.
One example of this was a very high precision piece of echo sounding gear the Navy made.
I had hoped to get some of this into oceanography, but one didn't seem to be able to get very much enthusiasm really for specialized ships.
very specialized apparatus.

And this indicates again why frequently I've liked to work with the Navy, because the Navy would be interested in the equipment that was, in oceanographic equipment, that was better than what oceanographers seemed to be interested in.
Part of it is a defeatist attitude.
They figured if there wasn't enough money for it, why dream about it?
But on the other hand, if you don't dream about it, you never get it.
Radio astronomers and geophysicists tend to use about the same wavelengths.
And radio astronomers and people who deal in commercial people, radar people, they have some very big dishes which are
equivalent to the optical analogs of lenses or reflectors.
And they make their money by having extremely high directionality, of having extremely high energy gathering power.
And this is a game we have not played at any very low frequency in oceanography.
The general concept of having a ship at least as big as an ordinary research ship, which is nearly
nearly all acoustic lens or acoustic reflector I think has a very real place.
And I've been spending a modest amount of my time in the last two or three years in trying to see if this makes sense and the
And while I haven't been able to get very much financing for it, I feel this is a direction which is probably inevitable.
If one reads Galileo, he was very excited indeed when he got a lens and could look in the sky with an added resolution that it gave.

I've been sort of concerning myself with whether if one had a reflector as big as 100 meters in diameter, which is small compared to the big tanker, what its implications to geophysics and echo sounding might be.

The military with either sonar or radar would find it very difficult indeed to isolate and understand a particular and classify a particular target if they proceeded with only gear which is obviously incapable of high resolution as what we routinely use in oceanography.
Another kind of thing I've gotten interested in recently is acoustics in the blind.
The very early days of acoustics in submarining and listening, you just couldn't help but have the feeling that as a professional listener, I must be a rank amateur compared to the blind person.

And in the field of oceanography, where nearly everything we learn is by remote instrumentation, the field of geophysics, where it's remote instrumentation, and measurements are either made in the acoustic field or in frequencies that can easily be translated to it, or they're made with sensors that can be converted to that.
Not that for a moment that I think that blind people can hear significantly better than sighted people.
And I've been warned to emphasize this.
But I have a very high respect for the true professional in almost any game.
And in acoustics, it must be the blind person that is the real professional.
I don't know the blind very well, but I understand instrumentation pretty well, and I understand the terrible, terrible limitations of instrumentation.
Even the most optimistic of the realistic computer people think it would be folly to think that in this century we could even come close to a typewriter that could
could type messages and multilingual and begin to catch the nuances and things like this, let alone hearing, typing what one person at a cocktail party says.

In the general ability to understand what they hear, to put things in a perceptual and geometric location, it may well be that the human mind, and I stress the human mind rather than the human ear, may have some advantages which we have not capitalized on today, whether this is in
understanding seismology, perhaps understanding earthquakes or so forth from the standpoint of science, getting better acquainted with the acoustics of fish.
These are fields which I think might be right.

Probably far more important from the standpoint of general society is that if you read the rehabilitation literature for the blind, it is nearly all on how does one find a job simple enough for a subhuman

where there may be classes of jobs in which their acoustical ability, of their resolution ability, or their ability of the portion of their mind which analyzes acoustic signals, may open up for them jobs in which they will be the professionals, quality control and production lines.
working with police departments to identify voices, and in structural mechanics.
